metadata.titel_preek: The Final Exit of the Baptized

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God through Christ and the Holy Spirit rescues the human subject from the 'dominion of death' and the illusion of self-justification, incorporating them into a life where death has already been defeated.

tekstueel_bewijs: God has reserved to himself the right to determine the end of life
Christ being raised from the dead will never die again
Baptism is the gift of a new spirit... the Holy Spirit

object.identificatie: Eternal Life / Deliverance from Death's Dominion
tekstueel_bewijs: the goal to which it is his will to lead it
arraigned... before the forum of God

ontvanger.identificatie: The Baptized / The Despairing / The Hearer
tekstueel_bewijs: all of us who have been baptized
One who despairs of life can only be helped by the saving deed of another

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Church (Witnesses like Mary V.)
tekstueel_bewijs: Baptism is the gift of a new spirit
The Master with whom my dear aunt walked

tegenstander.identificatie: Death / Stoic Self-Justification / Lack of Faith
tekstueel_bewijs: Suicide is the ultimate and extreme self-justification of man as man
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Death is treated not as a choice but as a 'dominion' and a power that only a divine act can break.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the baptized: yielding oneself to God and honoring life even in suffering.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Baptized Person
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The 'yielding' (Program 2) is only possible because the 'bringing from death to life' (Program 1) has already occurred.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has reserved to himself the right
Christ being raised from the dead
voorbeelden_mens_subject: Jerzy did what he had to do
We Christians need to become much more intentional

voorbeelden: If suicide must nevertheless be declared wrongful
someone who loved life too much to live it any other way
Do you not know that all of us...
One who despairs... can only be helped by the saving deed of another

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes the 'Pouvoir' (Power) of God over death, which compensates for the human lack of power in despair.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From the shock of S2 (Suicide) to the critique of ~S1 (Stoicism) to the resolution in S1 (Baptismal Life).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by redefining death: for the baptized, the 'final exit' has already happened in Christ, making suicide a redundant 'self-justification'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; death is seen as a rival dominion.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently places the agency of salvation and the definition of life in God's hands. Human action (yielding) is a response to a prior divine act (baptism/resurrection).

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: We Christians therefore need to become much more intentional about what we believe

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as active Subject of salvation
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: One who despairs of life can only be helped by the saving deed of another.
Death has no more dominion over him.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Mary V. is not presented as a moral hero to imitate, but as a witness to the 'Master's' presence.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The characters in Mary V.'s story are recipients of Jesus' presence and power, not examples of moral effort.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-justification; comfort in the face of death.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is monergistic (God's work) while ethics is the 'yielding' of the rescued.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon masterfully integrates the cultural crisis (suicide), the theological text (Romans 6), and the personal narrative (Mary V.).
spanning_punten: The tension between the 'heroic' Stoic suicide and the 'surrender' of the Christian.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Death has no more dominion over him.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit bestows the 'Pouvoir' (power/courage) that the Law cannot.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is seen as 'lack of faith' and 'self-justification'—a refusal to be a creature.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is driven by God's victory over death. The human subject is the beneficiary of a 'final exit' already performed by Christ.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain this balance; it is the essence of the Gospel.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Continue to contrast the 'must' of the law with the 'can' of the Spirit.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: Death is already treated as a cosmic enemy.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a profound example of grace-oriented homiletics, using the Actantial Model to displace the human ego as the hero of the story.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the shock value of the bookstore window, Greimasian analysis reveals that the 'window' is a manifestation of the Opponent (Self-Justification).
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Romans 6; semiotics shows how the sermon makes the hearer a 'Receiver' of the action described in Romans 6.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Stoic' and the 'Christian' are not just two different opinions, but two different actantial structures: one where Man is Subject/Sender, and one where God is Subject/Sender.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses Rutledge's rule effectively by making God the subject of the most critical verbs (save, help, lead, reserve).
